This executive summary provides a brief overview of the Risk Management Program (RMP) and the associated policies at the City of Commerce Water Treatment Plant, owned by the City of Commerce and operated by ESG Operations, Inc.



1.0    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



ESG Operations, Inc. believes it is important to provide a safe workplace to its employees and minimize the impact of its operations on the surrounding community and the environment.  Accordingly, ESG has developed proactive safety and environmental programs, which rely upon active employee participation and management leadership and support.  This same proactive philosophy was employed in the development and implementation of the City of Commerce WTP RMP for the chlorine system.  ESG Operations, Inc. has determined that the OSHA Process Safety Management standard also applies to the chlorine storage and chlorination process and therefore has prepared this RMP to comply with the RMP Program 3 requirements.  By doing so, ESG affirms its proactive safety and environmental philosophy and acknowledges the inherent value of full RMP compliance.



The RMP prevention program is arguably the most important element of the rule.  Program elements require the active participation of facility employees and management in conducting activities aimed at preventing accidental releases of chlorine, a regulated chemical under the RMP regulation.  If prevention activities could be completely successful, there would be no need for emergency response activities, since no releases would occur.  Accordingly, a well-developed and properly implemented prevention program will lower the possibility of an accidental release and minimize the consequences of a release should one occur.



ESG Operations, Inc. takes an active role in preventing accidental releases by ensuring that its employees are well-informed regarding the hazards associated with chlorine at the City of Commerce WTP and actively pa

rticipate in process hazard analysis.   The employees that work on the chlorine system are properly trained in the safe operation and handling of the chlorine system.  Refresher training is provided to the employees annually.  They are aided in this work by standard operating procedures.



ESG Operations, Inc. management understands its duty to provide a safe working environment and to take measures to prevent accidents which may have an effect on the surrounding community.  Additionally, ESG Operations, Inc. has established procedures for emergency notification and actions to be taken in the event of an emergency. 



2.0 Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



The City of Commerce WTP owned by the City of Commerce is located in Commerce, Georgia.  The 5 MGD facility treats water drawn from the City's water reservoir and is treated through a series of physical and chemical treatment operations before being pumped into the City's water distribution system for use. The City of Commerce WTP utilizes chlorine as a biocide in the treatment of drinking water and because of quantities stored, the City of Commerce WTP is regulated under the RMP rule due to the volume of chlorine stored and used at the facility.   As required by the RMP Regulation, ESG Operations, Inc. has conducted the Offsite Consequence Analysis.



3.0     General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention 

Steps



The prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps are described in detail in the City of Commerce WTP RMP manual.  The prevention program includes the following elements:



3.1    Process safety information, which includes information pertaining to the hazards of chlorine in the process, process technology and process equipment.

3.2    Process hazard analysis (PHA), which includes a systematic evaluation of the hazards of the chlorine process, identification of previous process incidents, engineering and administrative controls, consequences of failur

e of the engineering and administrative controls, facility siting, human factors, and possible safety and health effects of failure of controls.

3.3    Operating procedures, which include steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations and safety systems and their functions.

3.4    Training for each ESG employee operating the chlorine system at the City of Commerce WTP.

3.5    Mechanical integrity procedures to maintain the on-going integrity of the chlorine process equipment.

3.6    Management of change procedure to manage changes (other than replacements in kind) to the chlorine system.

3.7    Pre-startup safety review for additions or significant modifications to the chlorine process or any new regulated chemical process.

3.8    Compliance audits will be performed at least every three years from program inception to evaluate compliance. 

3.9    Incident investigation, to be conducted and documented for each incident that resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of chlorine from the facility.

3.10    Employee participation in the development and implementation of the facility RMP employee access to RMP information.

3.11    The Hot Work Policy prohibits hot work on or near the chlorine system when chlorine is present in the affected section of the process.  Contractor management program, to ensure appropriate evaluation and selection of qualified contractors for work on or near the chlorine system, proper notification of contractors regarding known chlorine system hazards and the emergency evacuation plan, limited access to the chlorine process and evaluation of contractor performance.



In addition to these elements, the chlorine storage area at the City of Commerce WTP is equipped with a chlorine leak detector that continuously monitors the air for chlorine gas.  If the chlorine sensor detects greater than 3ppm of chlorine, an audio alarm will be activated.  Management of Change procedures will be used for the upg

rades to the chlorine system.



4.0    Five Year Accident History



There have been no accidental releases of chlorine.



5.0    Emergency Response Program



The facility is part of the City of Commerce community emergency response plan which controlled by the City of Commerce Fire Department.  The City of Commerce Fire Department has communicated their desire to manage and respond to all hazmat incidents however ESG employees have been trained on the use of a chlorine B kit. The goals of the program are to protect onsite employees from the hazardous effects of a chlorine release and to minimize the effects of such releases on the general public.  This program is routinely reviewed and updated routinely by the City of Commerce to reflect personnel and regulatory changes.



6.0    Planned changes for Improved Safety



Ideas for changes to improve safety are actively sought from employees.  Employee participation meetings which focus on safety issues are held regularly at the City of Commerce WTP.  Employees are encouraged and trained to recognize hazards and to present ideas to eliminate them or to minimize the potential consequences of such hazards.
